etymology.description: a line on 刀 – cutting edge of a knife; the original form of 芒 (OC *maːŋ, *maŋ, “edge of a knife”).
etymology.interpretation: Originally marked the cutting edge on a knife, functioning as a simple indicator rather than a depiction. Over time this indicator became a standalone graph and later contributed to 芒, while meanings like “perish; lose” arose through semantic extension/borrowing into broader usage.

examples.chinese: 战败后，这个王朝走向灭亡(戰敗後，這個王朝走向滅亡)。
examples.pinyin: Zhànbài hòu, zhège wángcháo zǒuxiàng mièwáng.
examples.english: After the defeat, the dynasty moved toward ruin.

examples.chinese: 他在乱世中四处逃亡(他在亂世中四處逃亡)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài luànshì zhōng sìchù táowáng.
examples.english: He fled everywhere during the chaotic times.

examples.chinese: 亡者为大，家人谨守遗愿(亡者為大，家人謹守遺願)。
examples.pinyin: Wángzhě wéi dà, jiārén jǐnshǒu yíyuàn.
examples.english: The deceased deserve the utmost respect, and the family carefully honors the last wishes.
